text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new armand
hammer LP race music armand hammer is a
newly formed hip hop duo out of New York
consisting of MCS a lucid and Billy
woods Seleucid pretty underground guy on
the come-up you may remember him from
his numerous features on a bunch of
different Billy woods tracks and Billy
woods you might remember him from some
reviews I did of his recent LPS the
latest of which door candy I think might
have grown on me a little bit since I
initially reviewed it however I really
pronounced the name of that LP wrong
quite a few times in that review woods
and a lucid kind of debuted this duo a
little earlier this year back in
September with a mixtape that had quite
a few tracks on it it really seems like
a less polished and more grimy and sort
of more rough around the edges not
necessarily in a flattering way version
of what we're being delivered on race
music Billy pretty much still comes
through with that flow where it's like
half spoken word half passionately
shouted lyrically Billy's bars add up
into what feels like an incredibly
scattered narrative a lot of very gritty
and potent and very vivid but disjointed
imagery that sometimes until you've
heard the entire track and paid really
close attention time after time after
time
then you're able to kind of figure out
how it all comes together and tells a
story but still even not totally
understanding what a lot of these songs
are about Billy's very sharp wit and his
dark sense of humor really rings through
on lines like bad trip like you had to
take the bus back or weeks with no sleep
I'm living the dream
don't really want to know how it go like
ground beef a mother's grief Billy never
comes through on this LP with a sharp or
a speedy flow not really his thing
really he's the kind of guy instead who
will space all of his words out and
emphasize things like raw emotion
and concept a lot like Billy woods
history will absolve me from 2012 you
just get one track after another that
dives into a different theme some very
obvious from the lyricism and the title
of the track itself and others need lots
of replay in order to fully comprehend
because making sense of some of these
tracks it's really like putting puzzle
pieces together like the song hatchet
job which doesn't really tell a direct
direct story but if you pull all the
various lines together it kind of tells
something about doing dirt and not being
able to trust someone or some people who
you're working with they're dealing with
them sort of being in fear of a
double-cross and you've got moments
lyrical irritability Woods is saying you
know white man handshake twinkle and I
this new guy's got my spidey senses
tingling later in the track you're
getting these lines about maybe some of
this coming back to hurt your family and
on the track Sunnis blues you get what
is essentially a lot of imagery dealing
with much of the conflict going on in
the Middle East right now especially it
gets really vivid on the verse lucid
drops toward the end of the track with
children being mangled but maybe from
the perspective of the person seeing
this it's all for a just cause then
you've got the track Willy basket which
is a really standout track on here
because of how dark and just sad it is
with its subject matter you've got kind
of mental illness on this track kids who
are essentially underprivileged living
in urban areas and are suffering from
serious aggressive mental diseases and
don't really have anywhere or anyone to
turn to and the track actually gets
pretty disturbing with a lucid rapping
narrating about one particular kid and
sort of the suffering he's dealing with
and Billy would sort of turns it into
another standpoint of a parent or
relative or just someone being afraid of
what this kid might do just how he
lashes out song no roses is sort of
about these broken damaged relationships
which it seems like there's a lot of
adultery kind of being implied back and
forth it seems like there are some
emotional hang-ups on this track to that
I feel like I have to listen to a little
bit closer in order to fully get them
but then on the back end of this LP we
have a song like Nosferatu
- which feels like it's another
male-to-female relationship dichotomy
but what's going on here lyrically just
seems like a much more prime evil and
and physical sort of lustful kind of
thing you've got the song Duffy on here
which is actually a term Jamaican Patois
for spirit Billy Woods goes into grave
detail a situation that went on when he
was younger with his father dying and
his funeral and what seems like a lot of
people in his family turning against his
mother because there was some kind of
suspicion that his death wasn't
accidental and lucid comes through with
a verse on the back end of this tract
and what I like so much about him is
that they both take a concept and it
seems like both of them run in a very
different way with it and yet it ends up
so cohesive he goes into a lot of just
incantation type stuff ritualistic type
stuff lyrically talks a bit about
superstition as well it's a really
chilling track and maybe one of the most
spacious atmospheric instrumentals in
this entire LP then there is
hand-over-fist where it seems like we
have three different verses with a guest
rapper creature hopping on this song and
each verse seems to paint a picture of
people who seem to have lost their lives
to drugs or addiction there's just
really sharp detailed concept after
sharp detailed concept on this thing
where the wild things are you've got
kids kind of running wild in the streets
fighting gang activity just sort of
falling in with the wrong people
I love elusive ersan this track sort of
talking about sort of the initial fights
that kids get into being kind of a
gateway into that and having to stand up
for yourself and using violence in a
kid's youth as a rite of passage of
sorts and then we have Billy woods on
the back end I feel like talking a
little bit about the school system
failing kids too and then failing to
pull kids out of the cycle of violence
there's a really sharp line on here
saying Waiting for Superman the
classrooms full of kryptonite and then
there is new museum a track with four
different MCS including a lucid and
Billy woods I remember one of my
critiques of Billy woods door candy was
that we had this longer Posse cut on the
LP but I feel like it sort of took away
from the concept of the album or didn't
come through with a
strong theme at least in my opinion but
this track definitely does and it's kind
of a tongue-in-cheek look at the
everyday grind of the modern artist with
Billy talking about being addicted to
the Internet constantly refreshing
always looking for what people are
saying about you but always coming
across the same handful of mentions
you've got open mike eagle rapping about
his caliber as an artist and how he
should be brought out with the show dogs
and how he's so dedicated he never
breaks character he's so dedicated he
edits his own Wikipedia page a lucid is
rapping about NPR think pieces being
voted consistently averaged by other rap
fans and then bus drivers verses are
taking an interesting theme in that they
sort of bring the museum thing into
place on this track and he's shouting
like a ringleader a bit on this song in
my opinion and a lot of his verses have
to do with very avant-garde odd art that
when you see it you actually question
whether or not as art just go into this
expecting something kind of like a book
of different short stories with each
tale telling a different story or
painting a perspective or a character
portrait I should also mention loosens
rap style on this album because it is a
pretty sharp variation from Billy's and
you can really tell the difference
between these two rappers not only with
how they attack things lyrically but
with their flow the sound of their voice
two-for-one aloose it has this
incredible rasp that sometimes swallows
his words a little bit his rasp really
is overbearing sometimes kind of like on
Aesop rocks latest stuff and he
definitely flows a lot more
traditionally than a guy like Billy
woods does who really spaces his words
out however a lucid I wouldn't say
because of his flow is any more catchy
than Billy woods because a lot of the
flows that he uses are constantly
changing or really off kilter in a lot
of ways he's just as non-traditional
they're a pretty good match but I will
say that with over an hour of material
on this thing it can get a little
redundant especially with a lot of the
beats on here being so heavy electronic
slow noisy however each of these beats
do have definitive characteristics like
the really whaling off-kilter kind of
dissonant sense on the track hatchet job
or the
rumbling bass and the kind of
interesting cult sample on the song new
museum I just can't get away from cults
their sample too right on the hook hear
the song go outside the pianos on frog
and toad are friends as well as shark
fin soup are pretty nice addition the
beyond new roses is one of the speediest
and detailed on this entire LP and has
this incredible gospel sampling going on
in the background it's a chaotic beat
but elusive and Billy just cut right
through it
Willy basket actually goes in a trap
direction which we have Billy woods and
elusive flowing over this track in the
way that a modern young trap trapper
normally would but of course the story
and the personality that they bring to
the table and the very noisy sense in
the background really change up the
flavor the song hand-over-fist has these
odd reed instruments with this really
quirky melody sampled in the background
that I like a lot that give that song a
lot of personality and then there's the
song cloisters which is one of the more
toned-down soft and jazzy tracks on the
album really there's just a lot of
variety on this LP despite the fact that
it is so dark and the beats again are
pretty lumbering I would say that the
Achilles heel of this album is though
that it is so freakin dense and while
for people who are willing to give this
album multiple listens given they're
already into Billy woods and Anna Lucid
style this album rewards it pays out a
lot however it is so heavy with these
loose puzzling word assemblies that it
may scare off some newcomers to Billy
woods elusive Armand Hammer whatever
definitely not as many instantaneously
catchy tracks in comparison to door
candy or history will absolve me but in
my opinion an album that is about as
enjoyable as those two releases I'm
feeling a light too decent 8 on this
thing transition but if you've given
this LP a listen what did you think of
it did you love it hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantino Armand Hammer
forever
